title: Modus Ponens
description:
Prove the classic modus ponens rule: if we have `P` and `P -> Q`, then we can conclude `Q`.

**Goal:** `forall P Q : Prop, P -> (P -> Q) -> Q`

This is one of the most fundamental rules of propositional logic. In Coq, implications are proved by introducing hypotheses and then applying them.
hints: Use `intros` to introduce the propositions and hypotheses into your context
Once you have both P and (P -> Q) as hypotheses, you can use `apply` to use the implication
prelude: (* No imports needed for this basic logic proof *)
template:
Theorem modus_ponens : forall P Q : Prop, P -> (P -> Q) -> Q.
Proof.
  (* Your proof here *)
Admitted.
solution:
Theorem modus_ponens : forall P Q : Prop, P -> (P -> Q) -> Q.
Proof.
  intros P Q HP HPQ.
  apply HPQ.
  exact HP.
Qed.
